arachni_report.title: Web Application Security Report - Arachni Framework

issue.name: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
issue.description: Client-side code (like JavaScript) can be injected into the web application which is then returned to the user's browser. This can lead to a compromise of the client's system or serve as a pivoting point for other attacks.

issue.name: LDAP Injection
issue.description: LDAP queries can be injected into the web application which can be used to disclose sensitive data of affect the execution flow.

issue.name: XPath Injection
issue.description: XPath queries can be injected into the web application.

issue.name: XPath Injection
issue.description: XPath queries can be injected into the web application.

issue.name: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
issue.description: Client-side code (like JavaScript) can be injected into the web application which is then returned to the user's browser. This can lead to a compromise of the client's system or serve as a pivoting point for other attacks.

issue.name: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
issue.description: Client-side code (like JavaScript) can be injected into the web application which is then returned to the user's browser. This can lead to a compromise of the client's system or serve as a pivoting point for other attacks.

issue.name: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS)
issue.description: Client-side code (like JavaScript) can be injected into the web application which is then returned to the user's browser. This can lead to a compromise of the client's system or serve as a pivoting point for other attacks.

issue.name: Operating system command injection (timing attack)
issue.description: The web application allows an attacker to execute arbitrary OS commands even though it does not return the command output in the HTML body. (This issue was discovered using a timing attack; timing attacks can result in false positives in cases where the server takes an abnormally long time to respond. Either case, these issues will require further investigation even if they are false positives.)

issue.name: Blind SQL Injection (timing attack)
issue.description: SQL code can be injected into the web application even though it may not be obvious due to suppression of error messages. (This issue was discovered using a timing attack; timing attacks can result in false positives in cases where the server takes an abnormally long time to respond. Either case, these issues will require further investigation even if they are false positives.)

issue.name: The TRACE HTTP method is enabled.
issue.description: This type of attack can occur when the there is an XSS vulnerability and the server supports HTTP TRACE.

issue.name: A common directory exists on the server.

metamodules.description: Performs high-level meta-analysis on the results of the scan using abstract meta-modules. Before reviewing the scan results you are strongly encouraged to take full advantage of the data gathered via meta-analysis. They will help you shed light into the inner workings of the web application and even caution you about possible false positives and/or inconclusive test results.

uniformity.description: The same issue(s) persist(s) across different pages. This is usually a sign for a lack of a central/single point of input sanitization, a bad coding practise.

content_types.description: Logs content-types of server responses. It can help you categorize and identify publicly available file-types which in turn can help you identify accidentally leaked files.

healthmap.description: Generates a simple list of safe/unsafe URLs.
